objdescid.origination: Robert Blake delineator. The sketches and lettering on the verso of Object 18 may reflect Robert's attempts to draw subjects that had been set as exercises for him by older brother William, and, in some instances, corrected by one of them. See Object Note on Object 18.

objinfo.objorder: 1-18Bentley designates these as pages 1-16, A, P. Not included here, among the 18 objects, are the blank verso of Object 17 (Bentley page B) and the blank recto of Object 18 (Bentley page O). We are also not including Bentley pages C-N, all blanks, which are now housed separately from the leaves bearing the manuscript.
objinfo.numberleaves: 10Each leaf was originally half of a folio (2 conjugate leaves). Two or more leaves may have been removed, at an unknown time prior to 1905, between leaves 8 and 9 (Objects 16-17 as numbered here). The verso of leaf 9 (page B in Bentley) and the recto of what is now leaf 10 (formerly leaf 16, page O in Bentley) are blank. These blank pages are not reproduced here. Before rebinding in 1978, there were 6 blank leaves (Bentley pages C-N) of the same paper that bears the manuscript between what are now leaves 9 and 10 (Objects 17-18 as numbered here). As the sequence of watermarks and countermarks indicates, these blank leaves were once conjugate with the manuscript. The verso of the final leaf (Object 18 as numbered here and page P in Bentley) bears assorted drawings and inscriptions. It is included in Butlin's catalogue (no. 149) as "The Lamb Lying Down with the Lion and Other Drawings, from 'An Island in the Moon' Manuscript."
objinfo.watermark: crown and shield below, with animals, fleur-de-lis, and a harp within the shield.The watermark appears on leaves 2-8, 10 (Objects 3-16, 18 as numbered here). A countermark, consisting of the letters "G R" under a crown, appears on leaves 1 and 9 (Objects 1-2, 17 as numbered here).
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneObject 3 is numbered both 1 and 2 upper left and 5 upper right; Object 5 is numbered 3 upper left and 6 upper right. Objects 7, 11, 13, and 15 are numbered 9, 6, 7, and 8 upper left. All these numbers are in pencil. They are probably not written by Blake and thus are not included in our transcriptions.
objinfo.binding: quarter brown morocco over buckram boardsEach manuscript leaf is mounted in a paper frame. The present binding was created in 1978; formerly bound in red morocco with each leaf attached to a stub. The former binding included a proofsheet of Blake's woodcuts for Robert John Thornton's Pastorals of Virgil (1821) and a note from A.H. Palmer referring to their provenance.

provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Early history not known. Acquired before 1893 by Charles Fairfax Murray; given by Murray to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1905. A Fitzwilliam Museum collection stamp appears on the verso of the final leaf (Object 18 here).

repository.department: Department of Manuscripts and Printed Books

lg.l: In the Moon, is a certain Island near by a mighty continent, which small
island seems to have some affinity to England, & what is more extraordinary the
people are so much alike & their language so much the same that you would
think you was among your friends. in this Island dwells three Philosophers
Suction, the Epicurean, Quid the Cynic, & Sipsop the Pythagorean. I call them
by the names of those sects tho'though the sects are not ever mentiondmentioned there as being
quite out of date however the things still remain, and the vanities are the
same. the three Philosophers sat together thinking of nothing. in comes -
Etruscan Column the Antiquarian & after an abundance of Enquiries to
no purpose sat himself down & described something that nobody listendlistened to

so they were employdemployed when Mrs Gimblet came in the corners of herErdman reads the deletion as "tipsy" (page 449), Bentley as illegible (Writings volume 2, page 875), and Phillips as "tipsy &" (page 28).
mouth seemdseemed I dontdon't know how. but very odd as if she hoped you had not
an ill opinion of her. to be sure we are all poor creatures, well she seated
& listendlistened seemdseemed to listen with great attention while the Antiquarian seemdseemed
to be talking of virtuous cats. but it was not so. she was thinking of
the shape of her eyes & mouth & he was thinking. of his eternal fame
the three Philosophers at this time were each endeavourding to conceal theBlake may have first written "endeavourd" or "endeavoured" before altering the word to "endeavouring".
his laughter. (not at them but) at his own imagination, this was the situsituationErdman (page 449) and Phillips (page 28) read "imagination" as "imaginations".
ation of this improving company. when in a great hurry, Inflammable Gass
the Wind finder. enterdentered. they seemdseemed to rise & salute each other
Etruscan Column & Inflammable Gass. fixdfixed their eyes on each other. their
tongues went in question & answer, but their thoughts were otherwise employdemployed
I dontdon't like his eyes said Etruscan Column. he's a foolish puppy said

Inflammable Gass, smiling on him. the 3 Philosophers the Cynic Various attempts have been made to decipher the illegible deletions in lines 24-25. The deletion in line 24 appears to have been an inserted addition following "Philosophers" in line 25. Bentley reads the deletion as "Quid" (Writings volume 2, page 876); Phillips as "the older" (page 28); Erdman as "Quid" (deleted), replaced by "the Older", mended to "the Elder", deleted in turn (pages 450, 849n).
smiling the Epicurean seeming not studying the flame of the candle &
the Pythagorean playing with the cat. listendlistened with open mouths to the
edifying discourses.
Sir said the Antiquarian I have seen these works & I do affirm that they
are no such thing. they seem to me to be the most wretched paltry flimsy Stuff
that ever ___ What d'ye say What dye say said Inffammable Inflammable Gass, why"Inffammable": i.e., "Inflammable" (corrected by Blake, according to Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 876).
why I wish I could see you write so. Sir said the Antiquarian. according In line 32, the letters "ee" in "see" appear to have been struck through.
to my opinion. the author is an errant blockhead.__ Your reason Your reason
said Inflammable Gass_ why why I think it very abominable to call a man
a blockhead that you know nothing of._ . Reason Sir said the AtiquarianA word in line 35, presumably intended for "Antiquarian", is partly covered by an ink spot.
I'll' give you an example for your reason aAs I was walking ng theA word in line 36, presumably intended for "along", is partly covered by an ink spot.
street I saw a ^ number of swallows on the top of an house rails of an
old Gothic square they seemdseemed to be going on their passage, as Pliny says
as I was looking up. a little outre' fellow pulling me by the sleeve criesPhillips (page 28) and Erdman (page 450) read "outré", Bentley "outrè" (Writings volume 2, page 876).
pray Sir who do all they belong to, I turndturned myself about with great
contempt. Said I. Go along you fool.__ Fool said he who do you call

fool I only askdasked you a civil question __ here the I had a great In line 2, the deleted words are probably "here the" (Phillips page 31) preceded by a partially deleted em-dash, but Bentley reads the deletions as "----- had the" (Writings volume 2, page 876), Erdman as "here Etr" (page 450).
mind to have thrashdthrashed the fellow only he was bigger than I __
here Etruscan column left off__ Inflammable Gass. recollecting himselfIn line 4, part of the the "I" in "Inflammable" has been cut away.
Indeed I donotdo not think the man was a fool for he seems to me to have
been desirous of enquiring into the works of nature __ Ha Ha Ha
said the Pythagorean. it was reechodre-echoed by the Inflammable Gass to
overthrow the argument __Etruscan Column then staring up & clenchingErdman emends "staring" to "star[t]ing" (page 450).
both his fists was prepared to give a formal answer to the company
But ObuseObtuseaAngle. entering the room having made a gentle bow, proceeded"Obuse": i.e., presumably, "Obtuse".
to empty his pockets of a vast number of papers. turned about & sat
down wiped his head with his pocket handkerchief & shutting his eyes
began to scratch his head__ well gentlemen said he what is the cause of
strife the cynic. answerdanswered, they are only quarreling about Voltaire __
Yes said the Epicurean & having a bit of fun with him, And
said the Pythagorean endeavoring to incorporate their souls with their bodies
Obtuse Angle giving a grin said Voltaire understood nothing of the Mathematics
and a man must be a fool ifaithi'faith not to understand the Mathematics
Inflammable Gass turning round hastily in his chair said Mathematics
he found out a number of Queries in Philosophy, Obtuse Angle shutting
his eyes & saying that he always understood better when he shut his eyes
It is not of use to make In the first place it is of no use for a man to Erdman (mistakenly) reads an inserted "said" just after the deletion (page 450).
make Queries but to solve them, for a man may be a fool & make
Queries but a man must have good sound sense to solve them, a query
& an answer are as different as a straitstraight line & a crooked one, secondly
I, I, I. aye Secondly, Voltaire's a fool. says the Epicurean __ Pooh says the
Mathematician scratching his head with double violence, it is not worth
Quarreling about, __The Antiquarian. here got up _ & hemming twice
to shew the strength of his Lungs, said but my good Sir. Voltaire was _
immersed in matter. & seems to have understood very little but what
he saw before his eyes. like the Animal upon the Pythagoreans lap
always playing with its own tail, Ha Ha Ha said Inflammable Gass
he was. the Glory of France __I have got a bottle of air that
would spread a Plague. here the Antiquarian shruggd up his shoulders
& was silent talkdtalked for half an hour while Inflammable Gass talkdtalked
When Steelyard ^ coming in stalking _ with an act of parliament in his hand
said that it was a shameful thing that acts of parliament should be in a
free state, it had so engrossed his mind that he did not salute the company
Mrs Gimblet drew hier mouth downwards

Tilly Lally the Siptippidist Aradobo, the dean of Morocco. andBentley (Writings volume 2, page 878) and Phillips (page 32) read the deletion as "and"; Erdman (page 451) reads it as "Miss". Our reading of "and" is uncertain.

l.note: Phillips reads "Ma" instead of "M.rs Sigtagatist" (32). Bentley reads "Sistagatist" instead of "Sigtagatist" throughout (Writings volume 2), but, as Erdman indicates, "The name 'Sigtagatist' was first written 'Sistagatist' in most places, but mended" (page 849n). In lines 3-7, it is possible that the women's names replace the deleted men's names, but this substitution is uncertain.

lg.l: Miss Gittipin & M.rs Nannicantipot, All the three Philosophers &veryDeleted at the end of the line is a phrase, "All the three Philosophers", followed by words that Bentley finds illegible (Writings volume 2, page 878), Phillips reads as "& very" (page 32), and Erdman as "and the three Philosophers com[in]g" (page 849n). Our reading of these words ("& very") is uncertain.

l.del: Quid the Cynic. Sipsop the Pythagorean Suction the Epicurean
l.note: In the deletion, Erdman reads "& Suction" (page 849n).

lg.l: enterdentered the room& Gibble Gabble the wife of Inflammable Gass __ In the deletion, Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 878) and Erdman (page 849n) omit the "&". "Gibble Gabble the wife of Inflammable Gass __" may be part of a larger replacement of women's names for the deleted men's names in lines 4-6.

enterdentered the room & Little Scopprell enterdentered the room In the deletion, Phillips omits the "&" after "room" (page 32). "Little Scopprell ... the room" may be part of a larger replacement of women's names for the deleted men's names in lines 4-6.
(If I have not presented you with every character in the piece

call me Ass *Arse) ass _ "*Arse" apparently replaced the deleted "Ass" before both words were deleted and replaced by "ass_" (added in light ink). Erdman, on the basis of the asterisk, restores "Arse", to read the line as "call me *Arse--)" (pages 451, 849n).

said the Epicurean & claptclapped it on his head said the Pythagorean

Little PhebusPhoebus came strutting in
With his fat belly & his round chin
What is it you would please to haveBentley reads "would" as "wants" (Writings volume 2, page 878).

round his neck. here Aradobo lookdlooked AstonishdAstonished & askdasked if he understood

he was as great as Chatterton. Tilly Lally turndturned round to Obtuse

have livdlived so long _there was I up in a Morning at four

I was all in a heat, I would stand till I was ready to sink
into the earth, ah Mr Huffcap would kick the bottom of
the Pulpit out. with Passion. would tear off the sleeve of
his Gown, & set his wig on fire & throw it at the people
hedhe'd cry & stamp & kick & sweat and all for the good of

away. __You would You Ignorant jade I wish I could see
you hit any of the ministers, you deserve to have your ears

other __Then Mr Inflammable Gass ran & shovdshoved his head into

When old corruption first begun
AdorndAdorned in yellow vest
He committed on flesh a whoredom
O what a wicked beast
From them a callow babe did spring
And old corruption smild
To think his race should never end
For now he had a child
He calld him Surgery & fed
The babe with his own milk
For flesh & he could neer agree
She would not let him suck
And this he always kept in mind
And formdformed a crooked knife
And ran about with bloody hands
To seek his mothersmother's life
And as he ran to seek his mother
He met with a dead woman
He fell in love & married her
A deed which is not common
She soon grew pregnant & brought forth
Scurvy & spotted fever
The father grindgrinned & skiptskipped about
And said I'm made for ever
For now I have procurdprocured these imps
IllI'll try experiments
With that he tied poor scurvy down
& stoptstopped up all its vents
And when the child began to swell
He shoutdshouted out aloud
IveI've found the dropsy out & soon
Shall do the world more good
He took up fever by the neck
And cut out all its spots
And throthrough the holes which he had made
He first discoverd guts
Ah said Sipsop you think we are rascals & we think you are
rascals. I do as I chusechoose what is it to any body what I do

I do it because I like it My father does what he likes & so do
I. I think some how IllI'll leave it off there was a woman having
her cancer cut & she shriekdshrieked so. that I was quite sick

Chap 8
Steelyard the Lawgiver. sitting at his table taking extracts from HerveysHervey's Meditations

among the tombs & YoungsYoung's Night thoughts. This isfThe heavily deleted words at the end of the line are illegible except for "This is" at the beginning and a lowercase "f" midway. Bentley ventures to decipher "This is" (Writings volume 2, page 885); Erdman, more aggressively, ventures "This is unfair and ?I ?think" (page 456).
He is not able to hurt me (said he) more than making me Constable
or taking away the parish business. Hah!

l.del: O what a scene is here what a disguise
l.note: The ink used to delete this line is lighter than the original ink.

l.add: My crop of corn is but a field of tares

lg.l: Says Jerome happiness is not for us poor crawling reptiles of the earthThe illegible deletion is not noted by Erdman.

Talk of happiness & happiness itsit's no such thing - every person has asThe last word of the line is "as", though Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 885) and Erdman (page 456) read "a" without comment.
something
Hear then the pride & knowledge of a Sailor
His sprit sail fore sail main sail & his mizen
A poor frail man god wot I know none frailer
I know no greater sinner than John Taylor
If I had only my self to care for I'd soon make Double Elephant
look foolish. & Filligree work I hope shall live to see __
The wreck of matter & the crush of worlds
as Younge says
Obtuse Angle enterdentered the Room, What news Mr Steelyard __ I am
Reading Theron & Aspasio. said he. Obtuse Angle took up the books one
by one I dontdon't find it here said he, Oh no said the other it was the
meditations, Obtuse Angle took up the book & read till the other was
quite tird'tired out
Then Scopprell & Miss Gittipin, coming in SopprellScopprell took up a book"Sopprell": i.e., presumably, a slip for "Scopprell".
& read the following passage

An Easy of Humaning Understanding by John LookyeLockemanGent"Gent" is written over an obscured word ending in "man", deleted by wash. Erdman (page 848) and Phillips (page 43) read the deleted word at the end of the line as "Gentleman".

John Locke said Obtuse Angle, O ay LockLocke said Scopprell. aboutThe word "about" (an uncertain reading) is written over text that cannot be recovered. Bentley makes out "three words del" (Writings volume 2, page 886), while Erdman reads "its a book about" (page 456). Phillips renders the phrase as we do here, though he speculates further that the "first reading may have been 'Steelyard then' written in light brown ink, evidently the same ink used to write the first reading 'Gentleman' immediately above. 'Steelyard then' was then deleted with a full nib in a series of flourishes ending in 'about'" (page 83n).
Now here said Miss Gittipin I never saw such company in my life. you
are always talking of your books I like to be where we talk, - you hadWith this line, Blake shifts to using a lighter ink.
better take a walk. that we may have some pleasure I am sure I never
see any pleasure. theresthere's Double Elephants Girls they have their own
way. & theresthere's Miss Filligreework she goes out in her coaches & herBentley reads "coach" (Writings volume 2, page 886) instead of "coaches".
footman & her maids & Stormonts & Balloon hats & a pair of
Gloves every day & the sorrows of WerterWerther & Robinsons & the
Queen of Frances Puss colour & my Cousin Gibble Gabble says
that I am like nobody else I might as well be in a nunnery
There they go to in Post chaises & Stages to Vauxhall & Ranelagh
And I hardly know what a coach is. except when I go to

Mr Jacko's he knows what riding is & he will & his wife isPhillips reads the final word as "ride" but indicates that this reading is "conjectured" (pages 44, 84). Erdman and Bentley see only a three-word deletion: "he does not". Erdman omits the initial ampersand altogether (page 457). Bentley leaves it standing, undeleted (Writings volume 2, page 887).
the most agreeable woman you hardly know she has a tongue in her head
and he is the funniest fellow. & I do believe he'll go in partnership with
his master. & they have black servants lodge at their house I never saw
such a place in my life he says he has Six & twenty rooms in
his house. and I believe it & he is not such a liar as Quid thinks
he is. but he is always envying Poo Poo hold your tongue hold yourBentley (Writings volume 2, page 887) and Erdman (page 457) both read the last word of the deletion as "Envying".
tongue. said the Lawgiver. this quite provokdprovoked Miss Gittipin to interrupt
her in her favouritefavorite topic & she proceeded to use every Provoking speech
that ever she could. & he bore it ^ like a Saint than a Lawgiver and
with great Solemnity he addressd the company in these words
They call women the weakest vessel but I think they are the strongest
A girl has always more tongue than a boy I have seen a little brat
no higher than a nettle & she had as much tongue. as a city clark
but a boy would be such a fool not have any thing to say and if any
body askdasked him a question he would put his head into a hole & hide
it. I am sure I take but little pleasure you have as much pleasure
as I have. there I stand & bear every foolsfool's insult. if I had only
myself to care for. I'd wring off their noses
To this Scopprell answerdanswered. I think the LadiesLadies' discourses Mr Steelyard
are some of them more improving than any book, that is the way
I have got some of my knowledge
Then said Miss Gittipin Mr Scopprell do you know the song of Phebe
and Jellicoe_ no Miss said Scopprell __ then she repeated these
verses while Steelyard walkdwalked about the room
Phebe drest like beautiesbeauty's Queen
Jellicoe in faint peagreen
Sitting all beneath a grot
Where the little lambs dokins trot"kins" in "lambkins" is written over "s do" in "lambs do".
Maidens dancing loves a sporting
All the country folks a courting
Susan Johnny Bet & Joe
Lightly tripping on a row
Happy people who can be
In happiness compardcompared with ye
The Pilgrim with his crook & hat
Sees your happiness compleatcomplete
A charming Song indeed miss said Scopprell That was all forBentley reads "that" for "That" (Writings volume 2, page 888).
here they recievdreceived a summons for a merry making at the Philosophers
house
I say this evening we'dll all get drunk, I say dash. an Anthem
an Anthem, said Suction
Lo the Bat with Leathern wing
Winking & blinking
Winking & blinking
Winking & blinking
Like Doctor Johnson
Quid___ O ho Said Doctor Johnson
To Scipio Africanus
If you dontdon't own me a Philosopher
IllI'll kick your Roman Anus
Suction__ A ha To Doctor Johnson
Said Scipio Africanus
Lift up my Roman Petticoatt
And kiss my Roman Anus
And the Cellar goes down with a Step(Grand Chorus
Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho Hooooo my poooooor siiidesI I
should die if I was to live here said Scopprell Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho
1stVoWant Matches
2dVoYes Yes Yes
1 VoWant Matches
2d VoNo______
1stVoWant Matches
2d VoYes Yes Yes
1st VoWant Matches
Here was Great confusion & disorder Aradobo said that the boys

in the street sing something very prittypretty & funny about LondonFor "pritty" Bentley reads "pretty" (Writings volume 2, page 889). In lines 29 and 31, "about London / O no" is legible but deleted "by washing out" (Phillips page 88n).

tty Phillips reads this line as "My", "written in very pale brown ink", above "Nannicantipot" (pages 47, 88n). But it seems rather to be "tty", mirroring the letters just above, in "pritty", and partly erased.
O no about Matches Then Mrs Nannicantipot sung In line 31, "about Matches" could be replacing the deleted "O no" in the same line and/or the deleted "about London" in line 29.
I cry my matches as far as Guild hall
God bless the duke & his aldermen all

l.note: "When" is washed out but clearly legible above "Then", which replaces it.

lg.l: ThensaidsungScopprell
I ask the Gods no more
no more no more
Then Said suction come Mr Lawgiver your song and the Lawgiver
sungAs I walkdwalked forth one may morning
To see the fields so pleasant & so gay
O there did I spy a young maiden sweet
Among the Violets that smell so sweet
smell so sweet
smell so sweet
Among the Violets that smell so sweet
Hang your Violets hereshere's your Rum & water sweet O ay saidErdman reads the deleted "sweet" as "sweeter" (page 459).
Tilly Lally. Joe Bradley & I was going along one day in the Sugar house
Joe Bradley saw for he had but one eye saw a treacle JarErdman reads the deletion as "?one" (page 459).
So he goes of his blind side & dips his hand up to the shoulder in
treacle, here Il lick lick lick said he Ha Ha Ha Ha HaErdman reads the deletion as "ll" (page 459); Bentley does not note the deletion.
For he had but one eye Ha Ha Ha Ho then sung Scopprell
And I ask the Gods no more
no more no more
no more no more
Miss Gittipin said he you sing like a harpsichord, let your bounty descend
to our fair ears and favour us with a fine song
then she sungThis frog he would a wooing ride
Kitty alone Kitty alone
This frog he would a wooing ride
Kitty alone & I

This frogSing cock I carycarry Kitty aloneAn erased "f", clearly visible before "cock", is the most visible remains of what may be "This frog", which was erased and overwritten with "Sing co" in "Sing cock" (Erdman page 849n, Phillips page 90n).
Kitty Alone Kitty alone
Cock I carycarry Kitty alone
Kitty alone & I
Charming truly elegant said Scopprell
And I ask the gods no more
Hang your Serious Songs. said Sippsop & he sung as followsThe descender of a corrected "p" remains in the middle of "Sipsop".
Fa ra so bo ro
Fa ra bo ra
FSa ba ra ra ba rare roro
Sa ra ra ra bo ro ro ro
Radara
Sarapodo no flo ro
Hang Italian songs letslet's have English said Quid sing a Mathematical
Song Obtuse Angle then he sung English Genius for ever here I goBentley reads "Sung" for "sung" (Writings volume 2, page 891).
Hail Matrimony made of Love
To thy wide gates how great a drove
On purpose to be yok'dyoked do come
Widows & maids & Youths also
That lightly trip on beauty's toe
Or sit on beauty's bum

Hail fingerfooted lovely CreaturesAn illegible letter or other mark may be deleted between "Hail" and "fingerfooted". Phillips reads this as an (undeleted) short dash, "Hail - fingerfooted" (page 48). Bentley and Erdman do not note it.
The females of our human Natures
Formed to suckle all Mankind
Tis'Tis you that come in time of need
Without you we shoudshould never Breed
Or any Comfort find
For if a Damsel's blind or lame
Or nature's hand has crooked her frame
Or if she's deaf or is wall eyed
Yet if her heart is well inclined
Some tender lover she shall find
That pantedth for a Bride
The universal Poultice this
To cure whatever is amiss
In damsel or in Widow gayBentley reads "widow" (Writings volume 2, page 892).
It makes them smile it makes them skip
Like Birds just cured of the pip
They chirp & hop away
Then come ye Maidens come ye SwainsBentley reads "maidens" (Writings volume 2, page 892).
Come & be eased of all your pains
In Matrimony's Golden cage __
I None of Go & be hanged said Scopprel how can you have the face
to make game of Matrimony – What you skipping fleahow dare ye?Bentley reads "matrimony" for "Matrimony" and "how" for "How" (Writings volume 2, page 892).

l.del: IllI'll dash you through your chair says the cynic
Miss Gittipin) allways spoils good company in this manner & itsit's a shame

lg.l: Then Quid calldcalled upon Obtuse Angle for a Song & he wiping his face
& looking on the corner of the cielingceiling Sang
To be or not to be
Of great capacity
Like Sir Isaac Newton
Or Locke or Doctor South
Or Sherlock upon death
IdI'd rather be Sutton
For he did build a house
For aged men & youth
With walls of brick & stone
He furnishdfurnished it within
With whatever he could win
And all his own
He drew out of the Stocks
His money in a box
And sent his servant
To Green the Bricklayer
And to the Carpenter
He was so fervent

The windowschimneys were three scoreThe word "chimneys" is written over "windows" (line 40). In the next line, the letters "wi" in "windows" are written over "chi" (line 41), thus reversing the original order of those words.

The chiwindows many more The letters "wi" in "windows" is written over "chi" (line 41). In the previous line, "chimneys" is written over "windows" (line 40), thus reversing the original order of those words.
And for convenience
He sinks & gutters made
And all the way he pavdpaved
To hinder pestilence
Was not this a good man
Whose life was but a span
Whose name was Sutton
As Locke or Doctor South
Or Sherlock upon Death
Or Sir Isaac Newton
The Lawgiver was very attentive & begdbegged to have it sung over again & again
till the company were tired & insisted on the Lawgiver singing a song
himself which he readily complied with
This city & this country & brought forth many mayors
To sit in state & give forth laws out of their old oak chairsThe "s" at the end of "laws" is made unclear by what may be a spot of ink.
With face as brown as any nut with drinking of strong ale
Good English hospitality oO then it did not fail,
With scarlet gowns & broad gold lace would make a yeoman sweat
With stockings rolldrolled above their knees & shoes as black as jietErdman maintains that "jet" is "mended from git" (page 850n; also Phillips page 92n).
With eating beef & drinking beer oO they were stout & hale
Good English hospitality O then it did not faidl
Thus sitting at the table wide the Mayor & Aldermen
Were fit to give law to the city each eat as much as ten
The hungry poor enterdentered the hall to eat good beef & ale
Good English hospitality O then it did not fail
Here they gave a shout & the company broke upBentley reads "give" for "gave" (Writings volume 2, page 894).

l.note: The horizontal line terminates in an area of wash.

lg.l: Thus these happy Islanders spent their time but felicity does not
last long. for being met at the house of Inflammable Gass
the windfinder. the following affairs happendhappened.
Come Flammable said Gibble Gabble & letslet's enjoy ourselves bring the
Puppets. Hay Hay. said he. you sho. why ya ya. how can you
be so foolish__Ha Ha Ha she calls the experiments puppetsErdman (page 462) and Phillips (page 52) read "foolish.--".
Then he went up stairs & loaded the maid. with glasses. & brass
tubes. & magic pictures

Here ladies & gentlemen said he IllI'll shewshow you a louse. clBentley (Writings volume 2, page 894) and Erdman (page 462) omit the period after "louse". Erdman (page 462) and Phillips (page 52) read the deleted word at the end of the line, which begins with a legible "cl" and has been both struck through and erased, as "climing" (that is, climbing).
or a flea or a butterfly or a cock chafer the blade bone of a tittle
back, no no hereshere's a bottle of wind that I took up in the bogPhillips reads a period after the comma (page 52).
house. o dear o dear the waters got into the sliders. look
here Gibble Gabble__ lend me your handkerchief. Tilly Lally
Tilly Lally took out his handkerchief which smeardsmeared the glass worse
than ever, then he screwdscrewed it on then he took the sliders & thenBentley reads "slides" instead of "sliders" (Writings volume 2, page 894).
he set up the glasses for the Ladies to view the pictures thus
he was employdemployed& quite out of breath
While Tilly Lally & Scopprell were pumping at the air pump
Smack went the glass__ Hang said Tilly Lally InflammableErdman reads a period after the dash (page 462).
Gass turndturned short round & threw down the table & Glasses &
Pictures. & broke the bottles of wind & let out the Pestilence
He saw the Pestilence fly out of the bottle & cried out

while he ran out of the room. he come out come out Erdman reads the deleted "he" after "room.", less probably, as "Go" (page 462). Bentley reads the deletions that begin at the end of line 1 as "you are" (Writings volume 2, page 895), Erdman as "you / ar" (page 462), Phillips as "gas / --" (page 55). Beyond the descender on the first word, the deletions are illegible and the readings speculative.
we are putrified we are corrupted. our lungs are destroyd
with the Flogiston this will spread a plague all thro'through the
Island he was down stairs the very first on the back of him
came all the others in a heap
So they need not bidding go
Chap 11
Another merry meeting at the house of Steelyard the Lawgiver
After Supper Steelyard & Obtuse Angle. had pumpdpumped Inflammable
Gass quite dry. they playdplayed at forfeits & trydtried every method to get
good humour. said Miss Gittipin pray Mr Obtuse Angle sing us
a song then he sung

Upon a holy thursday their innocent faces cleanThis is the earliest known draft of the poem that, etched with designs, became "Holy Thursday" in Songs of Innocence, 1789 (Bentley plate 19). For accounts of the stages of composition, see Erdman page 850n and Phillips pages 18-20. Phillips prints a version of the poem that displays the differences between this and the etched version (pages 93-94n).
The children walking two & two in grey & blue & green
Grey headed beadles walkdwalked before with wands as white as snow
Till into the high dome of PaulsPaul's they like thamesThames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemdseemed, these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes were there but multitudes of lambs

l.del: And all in order sit waiting the chief chanters commands

l.add: Thousands of little girls & boys raising their innocent hands
l.note: This line was probably written in the break between the original stanzas 2 and 3 as a replacement for the final line of stanza 2 (line 21) after Blake had deleted it.

lg.l: Then like a mighty wind they raise to heavnheaven the voice of song A four-line stanza (lines 23-26) has been deleted. After it was deleted, the second couplet (lines 25-26) was not reused; the first couplet (lines 23-24) was rewritten and used to introduce the revised stanza below (lines 27-30).
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heavnheaven among
When the whole multitude of innocents their voices raise
Like angels on the throne of heavn raising the voice of praise
Let cherubim & seraphim now raise their voices high This unrhymed line is unique in a poem otherwise written in couplets. Erdman reads "Cherubim & Seraphim" (page 850n).

Then like a mighty wind they raise to heavnheaven the voice of song Lines 28-31 make up the revised stanza that replaces the deleted four-line stanza (lines 23-26) and the unrhymed verse that follows (line 27).
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heavnheaven amonggA second lowercase "g" is written over the original "g" in "among", perhaps to strengthen it.
Beneath them sitsit the revrendreverend men the guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity lest you drive an angel from your door
After this they all sat silent for a quarter of an hour & Mrs Sigtagatist Bentley reads the deletion as "Mrs Sistagatist" (Writings volume 2, page 896).
said it puts me in Mind of my grandmothersmother's song Bentley reads the deletion as "Grand" (Writings volume 2, page 896).

xThe voice"The voice" is washed out. These lines (35-44) make up the opening two stanzas of the earliest known draft of the poem that, etched with designs, became "Nurse's Song" in Songs of Innocence, 1789 (Bentley plate 24). The poem continues on the next page of the manuscript. For accounts of the stages of composition, see Erdman page 850n and Phillips pages 94-95n. Phillips prints a version of the poem that displays the differences between this and the etched version (pages 94-95n).

When Tthe tongues of children are heard on the greenThe spacing and lettering suggest that the line originally began "The tongues". Blake then inserted "When" before "The" and altered "The" to "the" to read "When the tongues".
And laughing upon the hill
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home ^ children the sun is ^ down
And the dews of night arise
ComecCome leave off play & let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No No let us play for it is yet dayThese two stanzas (lines 1-11) complete the draft of "Nurse's Song" that begins on the previous page (14.35-44).

And we cannot go to sleep till itsit's darkErdman outlines the sequence of revisions thus: Blake originally wrote "cannot go to sleep", emended it to "cannot sleep till its dark", and then restored the original "cannot go to sleep" (page 850n). Phillips describes a similar sequence, but notes that the original "go to" was overwritten by "get to" and "till its dark" was added to the line (to read "and we cannot get to sleep till its dark"). Phillips claims that Blake then restored the original "go to" by a supralinear insertion and deleted "till its dark" (page 95n). See note for line 4 for additional information about Blake's revisions to these lines.

l.del: The flocks are at play & we cantcan't go away
l.note: Phillips gives a plausible account of the revisions in lines 2-4 that hinges on the notion that Blake, "momentarily forgetting the rhyme scheme [abcb] established in the first stanzas on the preceding page", wrote line 4, made some adjustments in lines 2-3, and then recognizing "his mistake ... restored the original reading" of line 3, deleted line 4, and then "went on to write the next two lines" in conformity with the original rhyme scheme (page 95n).

l.add: Besides the Sky the little birds fly

lg.l: And the meadows are coverdcovered with Sheep
Well Well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laughdlaughed
And all the hills ecchoedechoed
Then Miss GittipinTilly Lally sung Quid Sung QuidErdman reads a lowercase initial "s" in the undeleted "Sung Quid" at the end of the line (page 463).

O father father where are you going This (lines 13-20) is the earliest known draft of the poem that, etched with designs, became "The Little Boy lost" in Songs of Innocence, 1789 (Bentley plate 13). Phillips prints a version of the poem that displays the differences between this and the etched version (page 96).
O do not walk so fast
O speak father speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost
The night it was dark & no father was there
And the child was wet with dew
The mire was deep & the child did weep
And away the vapour flew
Here nobody could sing any longer. till Tilly Lally pluckdplucked up a
spirit & he sung.
O I say you Joe
Throw us the ball
IveI've a good mind to go
And leave you all
I never saw saw such a bowler
To bowl the ball in a turd tanseyThe word "turd" is deleted and replaced by "tansey", written in lighter ink.
And to clean it with my handkercher
Without saying a word
That bBillsBill's a foolish fellow

l.del: He hit me with the bat
l.note: Erdman reads the beginning of the deletion as "To hit me" (page 850n).

l.add: He has given me a black eye

lg.l: He does not know how to handle a bat
Any more than a catErdman reads "a[ny bird the" (page 850n); Bentley "[ d he del]" (Writings volume 2, page 897); Phillips "an old he (page 56).
He has knockdknocked down the wicket
And broke the stumps
And runs without shoes to save his pumps
Here a laugh began and Miss Gittipin sungPhillips reads "began-" (page 56).
Leave lO leave to my sorrowsThe phrase "leave to" is presumably a slip for "leave me to". "O" is written over "l" (probably the start of "leave", conjectures Erdman, page 850n).
Here IllI'll sit & fade away
Till ImI'm nothing but a spirit
And I lose this form of clay
Then if chance along this forest
Any walk in pathless ways
ThroThrough the gloom he'll see my shadow
Hear my voice upon the Breeze
The Lawgiver all the while sat delighted to see them in such a
serious humour Mr Scopprell said he you must be acquainted with a
great many songs. O dear sir Ho Ho Ho I am no singer I must
beg of one of these tender hearted ladies to sing for me __ they all
declined & he was forced to sing himself
TheresThere's Doctor Clash
And Signior Falalasole
O they sweep into the cash
Into their purse hole
Fa me la sol La me fa Sol

l.note: Two lines (15-16) have been deleted, leaving them only partly legible. They may read (with Erdman page 850n), "How many Blackamoors / Coud sing with their thick lips". Blake may have originally started line 15 with "If" before changing to "How" (Erdman page 850n). Bentley reads line 15 less confidently: "If(?) we(?) manage(?) Blackamoors" (Writings volume 2, page 898). And there is considerable uncertainty in the reading of the first word of line 16, which may be "Will" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 898), "Coud" (Erdman page 850n), or "cant" (Phillips page 59).

lg.l: Great A little A
Bouncing B
Play away Play away
Your out of the key
Fa me la sol La me fa sol.
Musicians should have
A pair of very good ears
And Long fingers & thumbs
And not like clumsy bears
Fa me la sol La me fa sol
Gentlemen Gentlemen
Rap Rap Rap
Fiddle Fiddle Fiddle
Clap Clap Clap
Fa me la sol La me fa sol
Hm said the Lawgiver. funny enough letslet's have handelsHandel's waterpiece
then Sipsop sung
A crowned king.
On a white horse sitting
With his trumpets sounding
And Banners flying
ThroThrough the clouds of smoke he makes his way
And the shout of his thousands fills his heart with rejoicing & victory
And the shout of his thousands fills his heart with rejoicing & victory
Victory Victory - twas'twas William the prince of Orange

objnote.p: The blank verso of this leaf, designated as page B in Bentley and showing a considerable amount of show-through of the writing on this recto, is not reproduced here. Two or more leaves may have been removed, at an unknown time prior to 1905, between leaves 8 and 9 (Objects 16-17 as numbered here). Refer to the Work Information for more details about the manuscript. A diagonal pencil inscription at the bottom of the page, not in Blake's hand, reads, "a leaf is evidently missing before this one".

lg.l: them Illuminating the Manuscript _ Ay said she that wouldBentley reads the opening word of the line as "thus" (Writings volume 2, page 899).
be excellent. then said he I would have all the writing Engraved

instead of Printed & at every other leaf a high finishdfinishedPhillips reads the deleted word(s) following "other" as "sheet a" (page 60). Bentley notes only "word del" (Writings volume 2, page 899), while Erdman does not note the deletion.
print all in three Volumes folio, & sell them a hundred pounds
a piece, they would Print off two thousand then said she whoever
will not have them will be ignorant fools & will not deserve to live
DontDon't you think I have something of the Goats. face says he. Very
like a GoatsGoat's face __she answerdanswered __ I think your face said he is like
that noble beatst the TygerTiger __ Oh I was at Mrs Sicknakens & IBentley reads "Sicknackers" (Writings volume 2, page 899), Phillips "Sicknakers" (page 60).
was speaking of my abilities but their nasty hearts poor devils
are eat up with envy __ they envy me my abilities & all the Women
envy your abilities my dear they hate people who areBetween "people" and "who" is a stroke — probably a false start — that Phillips reads as a short dash (page 60).
of higher abiliesabilities than their nasty filthy Souls Selves but do you"abilies": i.e., presumably, a slip for "abilities". Bentley reads "abilies" as "abities" (Writings volume 2, page 899).
outface them & then Strangers will see you have an opinion __ now
I think we should do as much good as we can when we are at
Mr Femality'sdo yoyou snap & take me up _ and I will fall into such"yo": i.e., presumably, a slip for "you".
a passion IllI'll hollow and stamp & frighten all the People there & show
them what truth is __ at this Instant Obtuse Angle came in Oh I am
glad you are come said quid

objnote.p: At least some of the sketches and lettering on the verso (reproduced here) may conceivably be the product of both William Blake and his youngest brother Robert (1762-87). The awkwardness and redundancy of some of the work, the bare geometry of the head of the large lion(?) in the lower pair of animals in the upper left quadrant of the page, and the heavy overdrawing on some of the other animals are among the features that may possibly reflect Robert's attempts to draw subjects that had been set as exercises for him by older brother William, and, in some instances, corrected by one of them.
The blank recto, designated as page O in Bentley, and showing a considerable amount of show-through from the ink lines on this verso, is not reproduced here.

lg.l: B1William BlakeThe illegible letters and "William Blake" have been smudged.
BWilliam BlakeAll of the text in this line has been smudged.
NThe "N" has been smudged.

l.note: The gap indicates a partial letter. It may be the backstroke for a capital letter — perhaps "B".

lg.l: nnnNumerationAt the beginning of the line are two partial letters. The first may be a partial capital "T" or "F". The second is a small partial stroke. The second legible "n" has been smudged.
nnMThe text has been smudged.
mWllBlakeThe "m" has been smudged. The words "William Blake" appear to have been cancelled.

Lambnn "Lamb", written in a very small hand, is almost obscured by the first large "n". The second "n" has been lightly smudged. The illegible text at the end of the line appears to be a partial letter—perhaps "c" or "o".

l.note: The illegible text could be the capital letter "L" or simply a squiggle.

lg.l: nuBlaThe letters "Bl" (followed by an uncertain letter "a") are written in backwards lettering. They are also smudged.
frThe text has been smudged, and is written vertically in the lower right quadrant of the page.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The page is covered by scattered bits of handwriting and sketches of several animals, a single bit of vegetation, and the profiles of two human faces. Fragments of formal script not obviously connected to the sketches appear to represent practice efforts at making various letters and letter sequences. In addition, the word "Numeration" appears, along with a few whole and partial signatures of William Blake. With one exception, the handwriting is located on the left three quarters of the page. For further information on the text, see the detailed transcriptions and editors' notes. Near the vertical midline of the page are two human faces in left profile, one above the other. A pair of animals recline near the top left corner. The larger animal may be a lion (with mane and tail), the smaller one possibly a young horse or sheep. Below that pair of animals lie a second pair in positions similar to the first — and with similar forms. Thus the larger is perhaps a lion and the smaller a young sheep or horse. The heads of the smaller animals in each of the two pairs seem similar to those in two, possibly three, other sketches on the page: one below and slightly to the right of the rear feet of the larger animal in the top pair, another to the right of the heavily outlined horse's head in the lower right quadrant. The third possibly related sketch is a left-facing sheep's(?) head in profile. It is located just to the right of the pair of animals in the top left corner, among lines that suggest clouds. There are elements of several horses — their bodies and heads in various positions but all facing left — sketched down the right side and across the bottom of the page. In addition to the six horses' heads and the partial bodies, there are several wavy horizontal lines, some (perhaps all) of which appear to be attempts at outlining aspects of the bodies of horses. In the upper right quadrant of the page, a left-facing horse, its head partly obscured by ink wash, rears on its hind legs. Between the extended front legs may be a small flower or leaf. To the right of the head and neck of the rearing horse are the profiles of a second and third horse's head, both facing left. Beneath the front shoulders of the rearing horse are a fourth and a fifth horse's head, both again in left profile. The fourth, nearest the rearing horse, is an obscure design suggesting the head of a horse with a prominent eye. Just below the fourth horse's head is a fifth. Two dark, curved lines extend to the right. The upper one may suggest the front shoulder, back, and rear end of this (or perhaps another, or perhaps no particular) horse. A lower line appears to extend from the bottom of that horse's neck to the right and down. Left of the vertical centerline of the page, near the bottom, to the left of the human face in profile, is a sixth horse's head. And in the bottom left corner of the page are the headless torso and hindquarters of a horse, facing left.

component.illusobjdesc: A pair of animals recline near the top left corner. The body of the larger animal, possibly a lion (with a mane and tail) with a somewhat human face, faces left, while its head faces forward. Its front legs are spread, its left (and possibly the suggestion of a right) hind leg extended backward. A smaller animal, possibly a young horse or sheep, lies at the larger animal's left side. It faces right while resting its head, facing away from the viewer, upon the larger animal's back. Its front legs are extended; its hind legs are drawn up underneath or beside its body.

Below the first pair of animals at upper left lie a second pair in positions similar to the first. Thus the larger is perhaps a lion and the smaller a young sheep or horse. The larger animal reclines with the smaller lying against or beside it. The body of the larger animal faces left, its sketchy head apparently facing forward, its front legs spread and extended forward, its rear left leg extended slightly backward, with slight indications of its rear right leg emerging alongside the smaller animal's front legs. The larger animal appears to have a very long tail. The smaller animal, lying along or against the larger animal's left side, faces right with its head possibly resting on the larger animal's side. Its front right leg extends forward, apparently bent at the knee; its back legs are drawn up underneath it.

Near the vertical midline of the page are two human faces in left profile. The upper one has curly hair and what may be a prominent cheekbone or perhaps a stroke of an incomplete letter of the alphabet. The lower facial profile is partly obscured by diagonal lines ending in a jagged flourish at the mouth and then up to the right.
Just to the right of the pair of animals in the top left corner are lines that suggest clouds. Near the right edge of the clouds is the head of a sheep or lion in left profile.

The heads of the smaller animals in each of the two pairs of animals sketched on the left half of the page seem similar to those in two other sketches on the page: one is below and a bit to the right of the rear feet of the larger animal in the top pair, another to the right of the heavily outlined horse's head in the lower right quadrant. Both, drawn in right-facing profiles with their ears back, may be sheep, lions, or (conceivably though not likely) even young horses or pigs.

The heads of the smaller animals in each of the two pairs seem similar to those in two other sketches on the page: one below and a bit to the right of the rear feet of the larger animal in the top pair, another to the right of the heavily outlined horse's head in the lower right quadrant. Both, drawn in right-facing profiles with their ears back, may be sheep, lions, or (conceivably though not likely) even young horses or pigs.

There are elements of several horses — their bodies and heads in various positions but all facing left — sketched down the right side and across the bottom of the page. In addition to the six heads, there are several wavy horizontal lines, some (perhaps all) of which appear to be attempts at outlining some aspects of the bodies of horses. Some of these wavy lines seem to be aligned with, and thus associated with, the horses' heads, some not. In the top right corner, for example, two gently curved parallel lines extend from just above the head of the rearing horse to the right margin. Other curved lines down this side of the page may represent attempts to outline the bodies of horses.

On the right half of the page, its head partly obscured by ink wash, a left-facing horse rears on its hind legs. Its mane and forelock are visible, its mouth open, and its front legs, bent slightly at the knee, extend forward. Although only the right leg is clearly drawn, there are strong suggestions of left shoulder musculature and hints of hind legs and tail. Additional sketched lines right of the front legs may indicate multiple positions for the legs.

Near the top right corner of the page, to the right of the head and neck of the rearing horse, are the left-facing profiles of two other horses' heads. The uppermost head is held up, nearly horizontal. Its mouth is open and a lock of its mane extends above its eyes; a portion of its neck is visible. The lowermost head, mouth slightly open, is held nearly vertical, with a forelock and partial mane.

Beneath the front shoulders of the rearing horse are a fourth and a fifth horse's heads in left profile. The fourth, nearest the rearing horse, is an obscure design suggesting the head of a horse held at an angle of 45 degrees and with a prominent eye. Just below the fourth horse's head is a fifth, strongly outlined, positioned vertically with a few sketchy tufts of forelock and its mouth slightly open. Two dark, curved lines extend to the right. The upper one may suggest the front shoulder, back, and rear end of this (or perhaps another) horse. A lower line appears to extend from the bottom of the horse's neck to the right and down.

Left of the vertical centerline of the page, near the bottom, to the left of the profiled human face, is a horse's head, facing left, held vertically with a few tufts of forelock, mouth slightly open(?).

In the bottom left corner of the page are the headless torso and hindquarters of a horse, facing left. Only the upper portion of its rear left leg, extending backward, is visible, along with part of its tail.

Fragments of formal script not obviously connected to the sketches appear to represent practice efforts at making letters and letter sequences. In addition, the word "Numeration" appears, along with a few whole and partial signatures of William Blake. With one exception, the handwriting is located on the left three quarters of the page. For further information on the text, see the detailed transcription and editors' notes.
Just between the front legs of the rearing horse is a small design, possibly a flower or leaf of some sort.
